faq.question: Can I customize the XML root element name? What are the naming requirements?

faq.question: What should I note when converting large JSON data to XML?

faq.question: How to handle special characters and null values in JSON?
faq.answer: The tool automatically handles special character escaping in XML. For example, `<` becomes `<`, `&` becomes `&`, etc. For `null` values in JSON, they are converted to empty XML elements or special attribute markers, ensuring data integrity and XML validity.

faq.question: How does the JSON diff tool identify different types of changes?
faq.answer: The tool uses the jsondiffpatch algorithm to intelligently identify four change types: additions (green highlight), deletions (red highlight), modifications (yellow highlight), and moves (blue highlight). Through deep traversal of JSON structures, it precisely locates change positions and content, providing complete difference analysis reports.

faq.question: What is move detection? When should it be enabled or disabled?
faq.answer: Move detection identifies when array elements change positions rather than being deleted and re-added. Enable it when you want to track element repositioning (useful for sorted lists, drag-and-drop operations). Disable it when you want to treat position changes as separate delete+add operations (useful for independent data changes).

faq.question: How to handle comparison of very large JSON files?
faq.answer: For large files: 1) Use the unified view mode to save memory; 2) Enable 'differences only' mode to focus on changes; 3) Consider splitting large files into smaller sections; 4) Use progressive comparison for extremely large datasets; 5) Close other browser tabs to free up memory if needed.

faq.question: Can the diff results be exported for use in other tools?
faq.answer: Yes, the tool provides multiple export options: 1) Copy difference reports to clipboard; 2) Download JSON format diff files; 3) Export visual HTML reports; 4) Generate text-based diff summaries. These formats can be integrated into version control systems, documentation, or automated testing workflows.

faq.question: What are the different visualization modes for and when to use each?
faq.answer: Side-by-side mode: Best for comparing two complete datasets with clear before/after view. Inline mode: Efficient for focusing on changes within a single context. Unified mode: Optimal for large files with minimal changes. Visual mode: Great for presentations and reports. JSON mode: Ideal for programmatic processing of differences.

faq.question: What are the uses of Base64 encoding?
faq.answer: Base64 is mainly used for: 1) Transmitting binary data in HTTP protocol; 2) Email system attachment encoding; 3) URL-safe data transmission; 4) Converting images to text format; 5) API authentication token encoding. It converts binary data into printable ASCII characters.

faq.question: Does Base64 encoding increase data size?
faq.answer: Yes, Base64 encoding increases data size by approximately 33%. This is because Base64 uses 64 characters to represent 256 possibilities, with every 3 bytes being encoded as 4 characters. While data becomes larger, it gains the ability to transmit binary data in text protocols.

faq.question: What character encodings does the tool support?
faq.answer: Our tool supports UTF-8 character encoding and can correctly handle Chinese, English, special symbols, and various other characters. Input text is first converted to UTF-8 byte sequences, then Base64 encoded, ensuring proper handling of internationalized text.

faq.question: How to verify if Base64 format is correct?
faq.answer: Valid Base64 strings only contain A-Z, a-z, 0-9, +, / characters, must have a length that's a multiple of 4, and may have 1-2 '=' characters as padding at the end. Our tool automatically validates the format and provides error messages when decoding fails.

faq.question: Is Base64 encoding encryption?
faq.answer: No, Base64 is encoding, not encryption. It's just a data representation conversion that anyone can easily decode. If data security is needed, you should first encrypt the data then Base64 encode it, or use dedicated encryption tools.

faq.question: What is URL encoding? Why is it needed?
faq.answer: URL encoding (percent encoding) converts special characters to % plus hexadecimal format. Since URLs can only contain ASCII characters, Chinese, spaces, & and other special characters need encoding for correct transmission in URLs. For example, space encodes to %20, Chinese '‰Ω†Â•Ω' encodes to %E4%BD%A0%E5%A5%BD.

faq.question: Which characters need URL encoding?
faq.answer: Characters requiring encoding include: 1) Non-ASCII characters (like Chinese); 2) URL reserved characters (like &, =, ?, #); 3) Unsafe characters (like spaces, quotes); 4) Control characters. Safe characters like letters, numbers, -, _, ., ~ don't need encoding.

faq.question: What's the difference between URL encoding and HTML encoding?
faq.answer: URL encoding uses percent (%) plus hexadecimal representation, mainly for URL parameters; HTML encoding uses &entity; format for HTML documents. For example, space is %20 in URLs but   in HTML. They have completely different purposes and encoding rules.

faq.question: How to handle Chinese parameters in URLs?
faq.answer: Chinese parameters must be URL encoded for correct transmission. Our tool uses UTF-8 encoding, converting Chinese to byte sequences then percent encoding. This ensures Chinese parameter compatibility across various browsers and server environments.

faq.question: What to do when URL decoding fails?
faq.answer: Decoding failure usually occurs because: 1) Incorrect URL encoding format; 2) Invalid hexadecimal characters; 3) Incomplete encoding. Check if the URL is valid, ensure % is followed by two valid hexadecimal digits, and try partial decoding if necessary.

faq.question: What is UUID? Why use it?
faq.answer: UUID (Universally Unique Identifier) is a 128-bit identifier with uniqueness in time and space. Main advantages of using UUID: 1) Guarantees uniqueness without central coordination; 2) Suitable for distributed systems; 3) Extremely low collision probability (~1/2^122); 4) Can be generated offline; 5) Does not reveal creation time and location information.

faq.question: What is UUID v4? How is it different from other versions?
faq.answer: UUID has multiple versions, v4 is completely random number based. Differences: v1 is based on timestamp and MAC address (may leak privacy), v3/v5 are based on namespace and name hash, v4 is purely random (most commonly used). v4's advantage is simplicity, security, no hardware dependency, suitable for most application scenarios.

faq.question: How low is the UUID collision probability?
faq.answer: UUID v4 has 2^122 possible values (~5.3√ó10^36). Theoretically, generating 1 billion UUIDs has a collision probability of about 1/2^92, far lower than the probability of cosmic rays causing computer errors. In practical applications, UUID collision is considered an impossible event and can be used safely.

faq.question: What scenarios are UUID suitable for?
faq.answer: UUID is widely used in: 1) Database primary keys, especially distributed databases; 2) Unique identifiers in distributed systems; 3) File and resource naming; 4) API tokens and session IDs; 5) Message IDs in message queues; 6) Request tracing in microservices architecture; 7) Cache key generation. Any scenario requiring globally unique identifiers is suitable for UUID.

faq.question: What are the differences between UUID formats? How to choose?
faq.answer: Standard format (8-4-4-4-12 with dashes) is most common, suitable for database storage and API transmission; uppercase format is used as constants in some systems; no-dash format is more compact, suitable for URLs and filenames; uppercase no-dash is suitable for short code generation. Choice depends on specific needs: prioritize no-dash for storage (saves space), prioritize standard format for readability.

faq.question: How secure are the generated passwords? Why use random passwords?
faq.answer: This tool uses the browser's built-in cryptographically secure random number generator (Crypto.getRandomValues) to ensure true randomness. Random passwords are much more secure than manually created passwords because they avoid common patterns, dictionary words, and personal information that can be easily guessed or cracked through brute force attacks.

faq.question: What password length is recommended for different scenarios?
faq.answer: For general accounts, we recommend at least 12 characters; for important accounts (banking, email), at least 16 characters; for enterprise systems and high-security scenarios, 20+ characters. Longer passwords provide exponentially better security, and our tool supports up to 128 characters.

faq.question: What's the difference between excluding similar characters and ambiguous characters?
faq.answer: Excluding similar characters removes visually similar characters like 'i', 'l', '1', 'o', 'O', '0' to avoid confusion when manually typing. Excluding ambiguous characters removes symbols that might be interpreted differently in various systems, such as brackets, quotes, slashes, etc., suitable for scenarios requiring cross-platform compatibility.

faq.question: How should I manage and store the generated passwords?
faq.answer: We strongly recommend using professional password managers (such as 1Password, Bitwarden, LastPass, etc.) to securely store passwords. Never store passwords in plain text files, emails, or notes. Password managers can also help you identify duplicate passwords and remind you to update weak passwords regularly.

faq.question: How is password strength calculated and evaluated?
faq.answer: Our strength assessment considers multiple factors: password length (8+ characters get basic score), character diversity (uppercase, lowercase, numbers, symbols each add points), and overall complexity. The scoring system ranges from 0-100, with <40 being weak, 40-70 being medium, and 70+ being strong. We recommend aiming for strong-level passwords.

faq.question: How secure is the AES encryption algorithm? What scenarios is it suitable for?
faq.answer: AES is one of the most secure symmetric encryption algorithms currently available, adopted by the US government as the encryption standard for classified information. AES-256 uses a 256-bit key, theoretically requiring 2^256 attempts to break, which would take billions of years even with supercomputers. It's suitable for sensitive document protection, database encryption, communication encryption, and secure file storage scenarios.

faq.question: Why is an Initialization Vector (IV) needed? What is its purpose?
faq.answer: The Initialization Vector (IV) is an important security mechanism for AES-CBC mode, ensuring that even when encrypting the same plaintext with the same key, the encryption result is different each time, preventing cryptanalytic attacks. The IV doesn't need to be secret, but each encryption should use a randomly generated IV. Our tool automatically generates secure random IVs.

faq.question: How should AES keys be generated and managed?
faq.answer: AES-256 keys should be 32 bytes (256 bits) of random data. Our tool provides secure random key generation using the browser's cryptographically secure random number generator. In practical applications, keys should be securely stored, regularly rotated, managed using professional key management systems, and never stored in plaintext or transmitted through insecure channels.

faq.question: What's the difference between AES symmetric encryption and RSA asymmetric encryption?
faq.answer: AES is symmetric encryption using the same key for encryption and decryption, offering fast encryption suitable for large amounts of data, but key distribution is challenging. RSA is asymmetric encryption using public-private key pairs where public key encrypts and private key decrypts, providing secure key distribution but slower encryption. In practice, they're often combined: RSA transmits AES keys, AES encrypts actual data.

faq.question: Can data be decrypted if the AES key is forgotten?
faq.answer: No. AES encryption security is based on key secrecy, and data cannot be decrypted without the correct key. This is a security feature of AES design - even the algorithm designers cannot decrypt data without knowing the key. Therefore, secure key storage and backup are crucial, and professional key management solutions are recommended.

faq.question: What is the RSA encryption algorithm? What are its advantages?
faq.answer: RSA is an asymmetric encryption algorithm using public key encryption and private key decryption. Advantages include: 1) No need to pre-share keys; 2) Support for digital signature identity verification; 3) Relatively simple key management; 4) Widely used in HTTPS, SSH protocols; 5) Solid mathematical foundation with long-verified security.

faq.question: What key length should I choose? What are the security differences?
faq.answer: 1024-bit: Basic security, suitable for low-security scenarios; 2048-bit: Current mainstream standard, recommended for general applications; 4096-bit: High security, suitable for sensitive data and long-term storage. Higher bit counts provide better security but slower processing speed.

faq.question: What are RSA encryption data size limitations? How to handle large files?
faq.answer: RSA can only encrypt data smaller than the key size (e.g., 2048-bit key can encrypt ~245 bytes). For large files: 1) Use AES+RSA hybrid encryption; 2) Split large data into small chunks; 3) Use RSA to encrypt AES keys, AES to encrypt actual data; 4) Consider dedicated file encryption tools.

faq.question: How to securely manage RSA key pairs?
faq.answer: Private key security: 1) Store in secure locations, never share; 2) Use strong passwords for protection; 3) Regular backup and secure storage; 4) Consider hardware security modules (HSM). Public key: Can be freely shared and distributed, used for encrypting data sent to you.

faq.question: What's the difference between RSA encryption and digital signatures?
faq.answer: Encryption: Uses recipient's public key to encrypt, recipient uses private key to decrypt, ensuring only the recipient can read. Digital signature: Uses sender's private key to sign, others use sender's public key to verify, ensuring message authenticity and non-repudiation. They're reverse processes with different security goals.

faq.question: What are the uses of MD5 hash?
faq.answer: MD5 is mainly used for: 1) Data integrity verification (checking if files have been modified); 2) Data deduplication (same content produces same hash); 3) Cache key generation; 4) Data identifier creation; 5) Simple data verification. Note that MD5 should not be used for password encryption and other security scenarios.

faq.question: Is MD5 secure? Can it be used for password encryption?
faq.answer: MD5 is no longer considered a secure hash algorithm and has collision attack risks. It's not recommended for password storage, digital signatures, and other security scenarios. For password encryption, it's recommended to use specialized password hashing algorithms like bcrypt, scrypt, or Argon2.

faq.question: Why does the same input always produce the same MD5 value?
faq.answer: This is the deterministic characteristic of the MD5 algorithm. The same input data will inevitably produce the same hash value through MD5 computation. This characteristic makes MD5 suitable for data integrity verification and deduplication scenarios. Any tiny change in input will result in a completely different hash value.

faq.question: What is the length of MD5 hash value?
faq.answer: MD5 always produces a 128-bit (16-byte) hash value, usually represented as 32 hexadecimal characters. Regardless of the input data length, the MD5 output length is always fixed, which is one of the important characteristics of hash functions.

faq.question: How to verify file MD5 value?
faq.answer: Copy the file content into the tool to generate MD5 value, then compare it with the official MD5 value provided. If they match exactly, it means the file is intact and unmodified; if different, the file may be corrupted or tampered with. This is a common method for verifying downloaded file integrity.

faq.question: What advantages does SHA256 have over SHA1 and MD5?
faq.answer: SHA256 outputs 256 bits (64 hexadecimal characters), with security strength far exceeding SHA1 (160 bits) and MD5 (128 bits). SHA256 has stronger collision resistance, with no known practical attack methods, and is considered a secure hash algorithm widely used in Bitcoin and other blockchain systems.

faq.question: What role does SHA256 play in blockchain?
faq.answer: SHA256 is the core algorithm of Bitcoin and other mainstream blockchains, used for Proof of Work (PoW) mining, block hash calculation, and transaction ID generation. Its strong security ensures the immutability of blockchain data, serving as the security foundation for the entire cryptocurrency ecosystem.

faq.question: Is SHA256 suitable for password storage?
faq.answer: SHA256 itself is not suitable for direct password storage because its fast computation makes it vulnerable to brute force attacks. Password storage should use specialized slow hash algorithms like bcrypt, scrypt, or Argon2. However, SHA256 is commonly used for salt generation and API key verification scenarios.

faq.question: How to verify file SHA256 integrity?
faq.answer: Input the file content into the tool to generate SHA256 value, then compare with the official checksum. Complete match indicates the file is intact and unmodified, any character difference suggests the file may be corrupted or tampered with. This is the most reliable file integrity verification method.

faq.question: What are the characteristics of SHA256 hash values?
faq.answer: SHA256 outputs fixed 64 hexadecimal characters (0-9 and a-f), like: e3b0c44298fc1c149afbf4c8996fb92427ae41e4649b934ca495991b7852b855. Any minor change in input results in completely different output, and original data cannot be reverse-engineered from the hash value.

faq.question: What's the difference between SHA1 and MD5?
faq.answer: SHA1 outputs 160 bits (40 hexadecimal characters) while MD5 outputs 128 bits (32 characters). SHA1 has stronger security and collision resistance, widely used in Git version control, digital certificates and other applications. SHA1's computational complexity is also slightly higher than MD5.

faq.question: Is SHA1 still secure? Can it still be used?
faq.answer: SHA1 has been proven to have theoretical collision attack possibilities and is not recommended for new security-critical applications. However, it can still be used for file integrity checking, non-critical data identification, etc. New projects should use SHA-256 or stronger algorithms.

faq.question: Why does Git use SHA1?
faq.answer: Git uses SHA1 as object identifiers because SHA1 provided good distribution and low collision probability when designed. Although there are more secure algorithms now, Git's design makes accidental collisions almost impossible to affect actual usage, and changing algorithms would require huge compatibility costs.

faq.question: How to use SHA1 for file integrity verification?
faq.answer: Input the file content into the tool to generate SHA1 value, then compare with the official SHA1 digest. Complete match indicates file integrity, any difference suggests the file may have been modified or corrupted. This provides more reliable integrity assurance than MD5.

faq.question: What is the format of SHA1 hash values?
faq.answer: SHA1 outputs 160-bit binary data, usually represented as 40 hexadecimal characters (0-9 and a-f). For example: da39a3ee5e6b4b0d3255bfef95601890afd80709. Regardless of input length, SHA1 output is always 40 characters.

faq.question: What is hexadecimal encoding and why use it?
faq.answer: Hexadecimal encoding represents byte data using 0-9 and A-F characters, with each byte represented by two hex characters. It's more compact than binary and more intuitive for representing internal computer data, widely used in memory addresses, color codes, encryption keys, and other scenarios.

faq.question: Why are my Chinese characters so long after encoding?
faq.answer: Chinese and other multi-byte characters typically occupy 3 bytes in UTF-8 encoding, with each byte converted to 2 hex characters, so one Chinese character produces 6 hex characters. This is normal encoding behavior that ensures character integrity and internationalization support.

faq.question: What's the difference between hex encoding and Base64 encoding?
faq.answer: Hexadecimal uses 16 characters (0-9, A-F), with each character representing 4 bits of data, resulting in encoded length twice the original data. Base64 uses 64 characters, each representing 6 bits, resulting in about 1.33 times the original data length - more compact but slightly less readable.

faq.question: How to handle hexadecimal data in programming?
faq.answer: Most programming languages have built-in hex support. JavaScript uses parseInt(hex, 16) for parsing and toString(16) for conversion. Python uses hex() and int(hex_str, 16). Hexadecimal is commonly used in bit operations, memory debugging, protocol parsing, and other low-level programming scenarios.

faq.question: Why must hex strings have even length?
faq.answer: Because each byte is fixed to be represented by two hex characters, odd-length strings cannot correctly correspond to complete byte boundaries. When encountering odd length, you usually need to pad with 0 at the front or check if the data is complete.

faq.question: What is binary encoding and what is it used for?
faq.answer: Binary encoding converts characters into sequences of binary digits composed of 0s and 1s. Each character is converted to 8-bit binary numbers according to its UTF-8 encoded byte values. Binary encoding is mainly used in computer science education, understanding data storage principles, low-level programming debugging, and digital circuit design.

faq.question: Why do Chinese characters produce so many binary digits?
faq.answer: Chinese characters typically occupy 3 bytes in UTF-8 encoding, with each byte containing 8 binary digits, so one Chinese character produces 24 binary digits (3√ó8=24). This ensures complete representation of Chinese characters and international compatibility, which is the normal encoding method of the Unicode standard.

faq.question: What's the difference between binary encoding and ASCII encoding?
faq.answer: ASCII encoding can only represent 128 basic English characters, with each character represented by 7 bits. Our binary encoding is based on UTF-8, which can represent all characters worldwide, including Chinese, emojis, etc. UTF-8 is backward compatible with ASCII but provides much broader character support.

faq.question: How to understand binary data storage in computers?
faq.answer: All data inside computers is stored in binary form. Every 8 binary bits (0s or 1s) form one byte, which is the basic unit of computer storage. Understanding binary encoding helps understand how computers store text, images, programs, and various other data types.

faq.question: Must binary strings be multiples of 8?
faq.answer: Yes, because UTF-8 encoding is byte-based, with each byte fixed at 8 bits. If the length of a binary string is not a multiple of 8, it usually indicates incomplete data or errors. We check this condition during decoding to ensure data integrity.

faq.question: How to choose the appropriate QR code size? What are the usage scenarios for different sizes?
faq.answer: 128x128: Suitable for small displays and mobile screens; 256x256: Standard size for general digital use; 512x512: Suitable for printing on business cards and flyers; 1024x1024: High-resolution for large print materials and banners. Choose size based on actual usage scenario to ensure optimal scanning experience.

faq.question: What is error correction level and how to choose it?
faq.answer: Error correction allows QR codes to remain scannable even when partially damaged: L (7%): Fastest generation, suitable for clean environments; M (15%): Balanced choice for general use; Q (25%): Good fault tolerance for outdoor use; H (30%): Maximum tolerance for harsh environments. Higher levels create more complex patterns.

faq.question: What should I consider when setting custom colors?
faq.answer: Color selection principles: 1) Maintain sufficient contrast between foreground and background; 2) Dark foreground, light background works best; 3) Avoid low-contrast color combinations like yellow on white; 4) Test scan before use; 5) Consider printing effects and color accuracy; 6) Some scanners may have color recognition limitations.

faq.question: What's the difference between PNG and SVG formats? How to choose?
faq.answer: PNG format: Bitmap format suitable for direct use in documents, websites, and applications; fixed resolution may blur when enlarged. SVG format: Vector format that scales infinitely without quality loss; suitable for print materials and responsive design; smaller file size, editable with design software; recommended for professional design needs.

HMAC combines cryptographic hash functions with secret keys to provide message integrity verification and authentication assurance. As a security algorithm defined by RFC 2104 standards, HMAC is widely used in API security authentication, JWT token verification, digital signatures, and other critical security scenarios. This tool supports multiple secure hash algorithms, provides flexible output formats, and all computation processes are completed locally to ensure key and data security.

üì± Responsive design with perfect cross-platform compatibility

faq.question: What is HMAC? How is it different from regular hash functions?
faq.answer: HMAC (Hash-based Message Authentication Code) is a message authentication code based on hash functions combined with secret keys. Unlike regular hash functions, HMAC requires a key to participate in computation, providing message integrity verification and sender identity authentication. Even if attackers know the original message and HMAC value, they cannot forge valid HMAC without the key.

faq.question: Which HMAC algorithm should I choose? What are the security differences?
faq.answer: SHA-1: Basic security, suitable for low-security scenarios; SHA-256: Current mainstream standard, recommended for general applications; SHA-384/SHA-512: High security, suitable for sensitive data and long-term protection. Higher bit algorithms provide better security but slightly slower computation. We recommend SHA-256 or above for new projects.

faq.question: How to securely generate and manage HMAC keys?
faq.answer: Key generation: Use cryptographically secure random number generators, recommended length ‚â•32 bytes; Key management: 1) Store in secure locations, never hardcode in source code; 2) Use environment variables or dedicated key management systems; 3) Regular key rotation; 4) Separate keys for different purposes; 5) Secure transmission channels for key distribution.

faq.question: What are common HMAC application scenarios?
faq.answer: API authentication: Generate request signatures to prevent tampering; JWT tokens: Verify token authenticity and integrity; Webhook verification: Ensure webhook requests come from legitimate sources; Data integrity: Verify data hasn't been modified during transmission; Password storage: Enhance password security (combined with salt).

faq.question: How to verify HMAC correctness? What are the verification steps?
faq.answer: Verification steps: 1) Use the same key and algorithm to recalculate HMAC for the original message; 2) Compare the calculated value with the received HMAC; 3) If identical, verification passes; if different, message may be tampered with or key incorrect. Time-constant comparison should be used to prevent timing attacks.

faq.question: Why don't some colors have corresponding CSS names?
faq.answer: CSS only defines 147 standard color names (including transparent), while millions of other colors have no corresponding names. faq.question: Can the generated docker-compose.yml be used directly?
faq.answer: The generated configuration file follows docker-compose specifications and can be used directly in most cases. However, it's recommended to check and adjust according to actual needs: 1) Verify port mappings are correct; 2) Check volume mount paths; 3) Confirm environment variable settings; 4) Add network configuration, resource limits, and other advanced options as needed; 5) Complex scenarios may require manual optimization of configuration structure.

faq.question: How to handle commands containing sensitive information?
faq.answer: All conversion operations are completed locally in your browser, and command content is never uploaded to any server. However, it's still recommended to: 1) Remove sensitive passwords and keys before conversion; 2) Use environment variable files (.env) to manage sensitive configurations; 3) Don't include plaintext passwords in generated configuration files; 4) Add docker-compose.yml to .gitignore if it contains sensitive information; 5) Use Docker secrets to manage sensitive data in production environments.

faq.question: What if conversion fails? How to resolve?
faq.answer: Common causes of conversion failure and solutions: 1) Check if the command starts with 'docker run'; 2) Ensure it contains an image name; 3) Verify parameter format is correct (e.g., -p 8080:80); 4) Remove special characters and escape sequences from the command; 5) Try simplifying the command and gradually add parameters; 6) Refer to the tool's example command format. If the problem persists, you can manually create a basic configuration and then adjust.

faq.question: What image formats does the Base64 Image Converter support?
faq.answer: The tool supports conversion of all common image formats, including JPEG, JPG, PNG, GIF, WebP, SVG, BMP and more. Regardless of format, images can be accurately converted to Base64 encoding and perfectly restored to their original form. The tool automatically detects image types and optimizes the conversion process.

faq.question: What are the image size limitations? Why are there restrictions?
faq.answer: For optimal conversion performance and user experience, we recommend images under 10MB. This limitation considers: 1) Browser memory usage efficiency; 2) Conversion speed and responsiveness; 3) Avoiding page freezing. For larger images, consider resizing or compressing them first.

faq.question: How much larger do images become after Base64 encoding?
faq.answer: Base64 encoding increases image size by approximately 33%. This is because Base64 uses 64 printable characters to represent 256 possible byte values, with every 3 original bytes encoded as 4 Base64 characters. While the size increases, this enables transmission of binary image data in text protocols, making it ideal for CSS data URLs and web development.

faq.question: Is the conversion process secure? Are images uploaded to servers?
faq.answer: Completely secure! All conversion operations are performed locally in your browser, and image content never leaves your device. We do not upload, store, or record any image data. This local processing approach ensures the highest level of privacy protection, suitable for handling sensitive images and personal photos.

faq.question: How can I verify that the Base64 encoding after conversion is correct?
faq.answer: You can verify through the following methods: 1) Use our Base64 to Image function for reverse verification; 2) Check if the Base64 string contains only A-Z, a-z, 0-9, +, /, = characters; 3) Verify that the string length is a multiple of 4; 4) For images, you can preview the Base64 as a Data URL in the browser to see the actual image.

faq.question: What scenarios are dot matrix images suitable for?
faq.answer: Dot matrix images are widely used in: 1) Retro style design, simulating early printing effects; 2) Modern art creation, producing unique visual effects; 3) Web design backgrounds and decorative elements; 4) Poster and print design; 5) Brand visual identity systems; 6) Digital art and NFT creation. Dot matrix effects can give ordinary images a unique artistic and technological feel.

faq.question: How to choose appropriate dot size and spacing?
faq.answer: Dot size and spacing selection depends on the usage scenario: small images should use smaller dots (2-4 pixels), large images can use larger dots (5-10 pixels). Larger spacing makes images more abstract; smaller spacing preserves more detail. It's recommended to start with default values and fine-tune based on results. For print output, use smaller dots to retain more detail.

faq.question: What are the differences between color modes?
faq.answer: Three color modes each have characteristics: 1) Grayscale mode preserves image light and dark levels, suitable for scenes requiring rich detail; 2) Black and white mode has only pure black and pure white, producing high contrast effects, suitable for simple styles and logo design; 3) Color mode preserves original image colors, suitable for artistic creation and color printing. Consider final use and visual needs when choosing.

faq.question: How to choose between PNG and SVG formats?
faq.answer: PNG is a bitmap format, suitable for direct use and sharing, larger files but good compatibility, suitable for web display, social media, etc. SVG is a vector format that can scale infinitely without loss, usually smaller files, suitable for scenarios requiring scaling like printing, logos, icon design. If you need post-editing or significant scaling, choose SVG; if you need quick use and sharing, choose PNG.

faq.question: How is performance when processing large images?
faq.answer: The tool is performance-optimized and can smoothly process large images. Images under 10MB are recommended for best experience. For oversized images, dot size is automatically adjusted to ensure processing speed. All processing is done locally in the browser without uploading to servers, ensuring image security. If you encounter performance issues, consider resizing the image first or increasing dot size.
